metadata.title: Smart Strain Sensing Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Hydrogels with Nano Barrium Ferrite as Cross-linker

Smart Strain Sensing Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Hydrogels with Nano Barrium Ferrite
as Cross-linker
Hongbo Gu,1,* Hongyuan Zhang,1 Chao Ma,1 Hongling Sun,2 Chuntai Liu,2 Kun Dai,2 Jiaoxia Zhang,3,4 Renbo Wei,4,6,* Tao Ding,5,* and Zhanhu Guo4,*

Abstract:
Regarding artificial intelligence and wearable soft electronics, increasing attentions have been
dedicated to hydrogel strain sensors. However, traditional hydrogels are insulating and fragile.
To obtain a continuous and repeatable electrical signal output upon external stress or strain in
a hydrogel, the combination of good mechanical property, good elasticity and high electrical
conductivity is demanded. In order to apply hydrogel in the strain sensing field, in this work,
a smart flexible organic-inorganic polyanion polyacrylic acid (PAA) hybrid hydrogel is
designed with nano barium ferrite (BaFe12O19) as a cross-linker without adding any additional chemically covalent and ionic cross-linkers, which exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 1.22  10-2 S cm-1. Owing to high porosity as confirmed by scanning electron microscope (SEM), the
BaFe12O19/PAA hybrid hydrogel demonstrates a 100% recoverability and stable piezoresistive sensing performance with negligible hysteresis loops under cyclic compression loading tests
compared with the N,N’-methylene bisacrylamide chemically cross-linked PAA hydrogel.
This demonstrates that the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel is not only favorable to be used as a candidate for strain sensors in the soft electronics, but also facilitates the evolution of new
generation flexible, wearable, and human friendly intelligent devices.
KEYWORDS: Polyacrylic acid, barium ferrite, flexible, hydrogel, strain sensor.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With increasing development of wearable, flexible and human friendly soft electronic
devices, multi-functionalities and unique structure of soft materials for sensors, which can
transduce the external stimuli (for example, strain, temperature, humidity, pH, etc.) into an electrical signal (i.e. resistance and capacitance), are imperatively required.1 Hydrogels, as a soft mater (vs hard and frigid metals, ceramics, and carbon),2 which is composed of a
hydrophilic three-dimensional polymer network and a large amount of water, have been widely employed in the biomineralization,3 biosensors,4 cell modulating substances,5 drug release vehicles,6 tissue engineering scaffolds,7 and smart electronics due to their excellent biocompatibility arising from their unique soft-wet property.8 Strain sensors, based on the electrical characteristic change under an external strain,9 have attracted much more attentions in the fields of robotics, wearable consumer electronics, damage detection,10 human motion detection,11 and personal health monitoring, etc.12 Under exposing to a strain field, the
hydrogels should possess both good mechanical property and elasticity as well as high
electrical conductivity to supply a continuous and repeatable output electrical signal. However,
traditional hydrogels are normally electrically non-conductive and very fragile to external
stress or strain, and own low-stretch property and poor mechanical strength because of irregular chemical cross-linking points and broad distributions of chain length,13 which severely limit their applications in strain sensing fields.14 There are only very few report on the hydrogel-based strain sensors.15 Even the polyacrylamide (PAAm)16 and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)17 have been reported as the polymer matrix of hydrogel, the intrisically
insulating property makes these polymers have to combine with the common electronic
conductors such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, silver nanowire, or ionic ions (e.g. Na+, H+), etc. in order to behave as a pieozoresistive strain sensor and obtain an electrical
signal. In this situation, these common electrically conducting nanomaterials may have the
dispersion problem, which may further affect the electrical transport in a hydrogel, especially,

during the compression cyclic experiments. Therefore, it is required to exploit and fabricate
new hydrogel structure to overcome the aforementioned drawbacks.
Poly(acrylic acid) (PAA), known as a common negatively charged polyelectrolyte due
to the presence of carboxylic groups on its polymer backbone, has wide applications as a
functional material to control the wettability, adhesion, protein adsorption, and cell or bacteria growth.18 Generally, as a polyanion, the negatively charged PAA aqueous solution as well as
its hydrogels are electrically conductive. Particularly, PAA-based hydrogels may favor the
stable electrical signal output without dispersion problems and be the promising polymer
candidates for prepration of strain sensors. Yet, the strain sensing hydrogel based on the PAA
polymer matrix has been rarely studied.
Novel nanocomposite (NC) hydrogels, one kind of recently developed hydrogels, have
attracted more interests originated from their unique structures consisting of organic polymer and inorganic nanofillers and high mechanical strength.19, 20 Normally, in NC hydrogels,
instead of organic cross-linking agents, the nanofillers serve as physical cross-linkers to relax
the applied stress and postpone cracks by introducing random conformations into flexible
polymer chains, and further improving the mechanical properties of NC hydrogels. The commonly used inorganic nanofillers include clay nanosheets/ceramic oxides/metals,21 carbon nanodots, carbon nanotubes, and graphene oxide, etc.22 However, since the scarcity of functional groups on the surface of nanofillers,23 it is normally needed to chemically modify
the surface of nanofillers with multi-functional groups such as hydroxyl, carbonyl, and
epoxide or add a small amount of chemically covalent and ionic cross-linkers (for example, N,N’-methylene bisacrylamide (MBA)) to form NC hydrogels.24 Though the reported NC
hydrogels exhibit excellent mechanical properties, with the aim to obtain hydrogel strain
sensors with good electrical signal performance, high elasticity is also demanded. Thus, the
exploration of novel physical cross-linkers and the fabrication of new structure of NC
hydrogels are still challenging.

Barium ferrite (BaFe12O19), as one of the well-known hexagonal hard magnetic
materials, has been widely adopted for high density recording media, microwave devices, and electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding25 due to its large saturation magnetization (Ms, 72 emu g-1), high coercivity (Hc, around 1 - 5 kOe), excellent chemical stability and corrosion resistivity as well as high Curie temperature.26 In coordination chemistry, as the fifth element in group 2 and rare earth metal, Ba2+ cations have the possibility to form Ba2+-ligand complex.27 Meanwhile, Fe3+ is also capable to create the transition metal complex. Thus,
BaFe12O19 is a good candidate as a physical cross-linker in the preparation of NC hydrogels. Nevertheless, there is no report regarding the BaFe12O19 nanoparticles based NC hydrogels for strain sensors.
In this work, a novel electrically conducting polyanion PAA hydrogel with BaFe12O19
nanoparticles as physical cross-linkers for a flexible strain controlled manipulator has been
prepared by a one-step in-situ polymerization of acrylic acid in the BaFe12O19 nanoparticle aqueous suspensions without adding any additional chemically covalent and ionic
cross-linkers. The formation of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel is related to the coordination chemistry between Ba and Fe elements with the carboxyl groups of PAA polymer as indicated
by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, and
Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The BaFe12O19/PAA hybrid hydrogel possesses an obvious porous structure confirmed by scanning electron microscope (SEM).
Consequently, the BaFe12O19/PAA hybrid hydrogel exhibits a good mechanical property and compression cyclic property with negligible hysteresis loops and 100% recoverability as well
as superior pieozoresistive strain sensing behaviours compared with the chemically covalent
cross-linked PAA with MBA, in which the electrical signal is obviously decreased with cyclic
strain.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials

Barium nitrate (Ba(NO3)2, ≥99.5%), iron nitrate (nonahydrate) (Fe(NO3)39H2O,
≥98.5%), ammonia (NH3H2O, 25 ~ 28 wt%), citric acid (C8H8O7H2O, ≥99.5%), ammonium
persulfate (APS) ((NH4)S2O8, ≥98.0%), and N,N’-methylene bisacrylamide (C7H10N2O2, MBA, ≥98.0%) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Company, Inc. Acrylic acid (AA,
>99%) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Fe3O4 nanoparticles with an average size of 20 nm were obtained from Nanjing Emperor Nano Material Co., Ltd.
All the chemicals were used as-received without any further treatment.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of Barium Ferrite Nanoparticles
sections.text:
The barium ferrite (BaFe12O19) nanoparticles were synthesized by sol-gel and
self-propagating combustion method as reported in our previous work.26 Briefly, the citric
acid, Ba(NO3)2 and Fe(NO3)3 with a molar ratio of citric acid: Ba(NO3)2: Fe(NO3)3 = 13: 1: 12 were mixed with 10 mL deionized water for dissolution. Then ammonia was dripped to adjust the pH value around 7. After magnetically stirring at 80 oC for 1 - 2 h in a water bath, the solution became sol-gel. This sol-gel was self-ignited at 200 - 220 oC. Lastly, this precursor was grinded in a mortar and pestle and put into a tube furnace to anneal at 900 oC
for 10 h to obtain a well-crystallized BaFe12O19 nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of Barium Ferrite/Polyacrylic Acid Hydrogel
sections.text:
PAA, a water soluble and biocompatible polymer, has considerable applications in the
biomedical fields.28 Therefore, in this work, PAA was chosen as the polymer matrix of
hydrogel. The BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel was in-situ polymerized of monomer AA in the aqueous suspension of BaFe12O19. The BaFe12O19 nanoparticles were firstly dispersed in a beaker contained 100 mL deionized water and 1.0 g APS under 20-min sonication. Secondly,
the suspension was transferred into a three-neck flask under mechanical stirring and sonication for 1 hour at 25 oC. Then with the water bath heated to 70 oC, the AA monomers
were added into the above mixed solution dropwise. Afterward, the reaction was conducted at

70 oC for approximate 1 - 2 hours until the viscosity of solution was increased obviously.
Finally, the mixture was poured into a cylinder polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) mold and kept in an oven at 60 oC for 24 h to produce the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels. In this work, the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels with a BaFe12O19 loading of 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5 wt% were prepared. In comparison, the PAA hydrogel cross-linked with 0.3 wt% chemical MBA was also prepared
with the same procedure, which is indexed as MBA/PAA hydrogel.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterizations
sections.text:
The microstructures of BaFe12O19 nanoparticles and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels were
observed on a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Hitachi S-4800 system).
A thin gold layer with 3 nm thick was sputtered on the SEM specimens. The SEM
measurements for the MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel were performed after freeze-drying. The elemental mapping was carried out with an Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, Hitachi SU8020). The TGA test was performed at a heating rate of 5 oC min-1 under an air flow rate of 60 mL min-1 from 25 to 800 oC.
The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, Thermo Scientific, Thermo
Nicolet NEXUS with an ATR accessory) in the range from 500 to 4000 cm-1 with a resolution of 4 cm-1 was used to study the formation mechanism of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel. The crystalline structures of BaFe12O19, MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel were proceeded through powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis using a Bruker AXS D8
Discover diffractometer with GADDS (General Area Detector Diffraction System)
manipulating with a Cu-Kα radiation source filtered with a graphite monochromator (λ =

sections.heading: 1.5406 Å).
sections.text:
The ionic conductivity (i) of hydrogels was determined by electrochemical
impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with copper blocking electrodes using a CHI602E Instrument
Potentiostat (Shanghai ChenHua Instrument Co., Ltd.) over the frequency range from 100,000
to 0.01 Hz at an amplitude of 0 mV referring to the open circuit potential. The hydrogel with

thickness of around 5 mm was filled between mirror-finished copper electrodes.29 The
measurement was carried out at room temperature and the setup is illustrated in Figure S5.
For compression testing, cylindrical samples of the as-prepared PAA and BaFe-
12O19/PAA hydrogels with a diameter of 25 mm and height of 25 mm were used in a unidirectional tensile test machine (Shanghai Xieqiang Instrument Technology Co. Ltd.). The crosshead speed of 10 mm min-1 was used and the strain (%) was computed by dividing the
jogging displacement with the initial gauge length of 25 mm. The compression strength was
obtained by the strain at deformation of 80%. A schematic of the strain sensing measurement
is depicted in Figure S7. The strain sensing compression tests were carried out via a universal
testing machine with a 100 N load cell (UTM2203, Shenzhen Suns Technology Stock Co. Ltd,
China). For the compression hysteresis experiments, cylindrical hydrogels with a diameter of
18 mm and a height of 10 mm were pressed to a compression strain of 40% with a gage
length of 10 mm. The volume resistance was performed on a precision digital resistor
(Tektronix, DMM 4050). As shown in Figure S7, the cylindrical hydrogels were put between
two copper tap electrodes. The precision digital resistor coupled with the universal testing
machine was connected to a computer to record the strain sensing behavior. The
measurements were repeated for 3-5 times on different specimens for each sample for
accuracy. The relative resistance was indexed by R/R0, where R stands for the resistance
change during the compression testing process, and R0 represents the initial resistance of hydrogels. After the compression hysteresis tests, the recovery ratio (Tr) of hydrogel is calculated by Eq. (1):30
r c 0/T T T (1)
where Tc is the residual strain, and T0 is the original strain of hydrogel.

sections.heading: 3. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Characterization of nanoBaFe12O19 and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels

Fig. S1 shows the SEM images of as-prepared BaFe12O19 nanoparticles. It’s seen that
the BaFe12O19 nanoparticles manifest the particulate structure and a smooth surface with an average size of 60-80 nm estimated from the Nano measure 1.2 software. Fig. 1A shows the
photo of as-prepared cylindrical BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel. As depicted in Fig. 1B&C, the photographs of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel clearly displays excellent elasticity and toughness, which can easily restore to its original columnar shape as soon as the stress is removed. Even
the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels undergo a high strain of 133 N, it recovers quickly after releasing the compression stress without obvious damage, Fig. 1D-F. In order to differentiate
MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel, the SEM, FT-IR spectra and XRD patterns of MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel have been conducted. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of MBA/PAA and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels with different BaFe12O19 nanoparticle loadings after freeze-drying. It turns out that the microstructures of both MBA/PAA and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels ehibit 3D porous frameworks. Nevertheless, for the MBA/PAA hydrogel, owing to the chemically covalent bonding between MBA and
PAA polymer chains, the MBA/PAA hydrogel forms a dense space grid microstructure with
different sizes of pores, Fig. 2A, which possesses similar morphologies to the hydrogels cross-linked by the common chemically covalent agents.31 In contrast, the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels, Fig. 2B-D, reveal a relatively porous structure, corresponding to the formation of a hydrogel matrix,32 and the pores are vividly bigger than those of MBA/PAA hydrogel,
especially for the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels with a BaFe12O19 loading of 0.5 wt%. The microstructure differences of these two kinds of hydrogels may lead to different mechanical
properties. The highly porous structure of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel can provide PAA polymers with sufficient mobility, which may faciliate the rapid response of hydrogel to the external stress/strain.17
Fig. 3A shows the FT-IR spectra of BaFe12O19, MBA/PAA hydrogel and
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel with a BaFe12O19 nanoparticle loading of 0.3 wt%. For the

as-prepared BaFe12O19 nanoparticles, two absorption peaks located at 540 and 575 cm-1 are assigned to the stretching vibrations of Fe-O33 and Ba-O bands,34 respectively. In the FT-IR spectrum of MBA/PAA hydrogel, the broad peak at around 3332 cm-1 is associated with the H-O stretching vibrations.35 The bands located at 1636 and 1263 cm-1 are due to the C=O and
C-O stretching vibration from the carboxylic groups, accordingly. An obvious shoulder peak at around 1700 cm-1 as marked by the rectangle is due to the C=O stretching vibration from
the MBA molecules. Most of these characteristic absorption peaks appear in the FT-IR spectrum of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel, except the shoulder peak at around 1700 cm-1 (which is related to the MBA molecules) as expected. Most importantly, the Fe-O and Ba-O stretching vibrations at around 550 cm-1 from BaFe12O19 nanoparticles disappear in the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel. This may be from the following reasons: on one hand, this is due to the low content of BaFe12O19 nanoparticles in the hydrogel (0.3 wt%); on the other hand, the Ba and Fe elements may participate in the construction of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel since the Ba and Fe have strong coordinations with carboxylic groups in PAA.
Fig. 3B shows the XRD diffraction patterns of as-prepared BaFe12O19 nanoparticles,
which are consistent with the standard JCPDS No. 39-1433 of typical M type BaFe12O19, illustrating the successful preparation of BaFe12O19 nanoparticles. Nevertheless, the broad peaks are observed in the MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel without any evident sharp diffraction peaks. The 2-dimensional elemental distributions in BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel are clearly demonstrated, Fig. 3C. The zero loss image of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel is shown on the left and the elemental distributions for Ba, Fe, O, C elements are illustrated
on the right. Obviously, Ba and Fe elements are uniformly distributed within PAA hydrogel
matrix, implying that the Ba and Fe elements favour the formation of PAA hydrogel.
Moreover, in order to confirm the contribution of Ba and Fe elements to the structure of
hydrogel, the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were used to fabricate PAA hydrogel for comparison. Unfortunately, the PAA hydrogel cross-linked by Fe3O4 nanoparticles can not be constructed,

implying the important role of existing both Ba and Fe elements in the PAA hydrogel

the construction of PAA hydrogels. The proposed formation mechanism of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel is depicted in Scheme 1.

sections.heading: 3.2. Ionic coductivity of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels
sections.text:
Since the PAA hydrogel is a polyelectrolyte, the electrical conductivity of PAA
hydrogel is dominated by the ionic conductivity (i). The i could be acquired from
electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement through the Nyquist plot
(imiganary impedence Z" vs real impedence Z'). The measured Nyquist plots Z' ～ - Z" for
the MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel with a nanoparticle loading of 0.3 wt% are displayed in Fig. 4. Both the MBA/PAA hydrogel and the 0.3 wt% of
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel show the semicircle at the high frequency region accompanied by a short line at the low frequency region as expected. Therefore, the i could be computed from Eq. (2):36
i = d/(RbS) (2)
where d is the thickness of hydrogel, S is the area of the hydrogel, and Rb is the resistiance of hydrogels, which could be determined from Z' at high frequency of 20 kHz. The estimated Rb for the MBA/PAA hydrogel and the 0.3 wt% of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel was 27.69 and 26.08  respectively The calculated i for the MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel was 9.38 and 12.2 mS cm-1, exhibiting a relatively high ionic conductivity.37

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanical Properties of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels
sections.text:
The compressibility is a vital factor for a material to apply in the strain sensing field.38
Fig. 4A shows the compression stress-strain curves of MBA/PAA hydrogel and
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel with different BaFe12O19 nanoparticle loadings. All these hydrogels have been compressed to 80% for easy comparison. The MBA/PAA hydrogel manifests the
Jo ur

highest average compression strength up to 130.4 kPa, whereas the average compression
strength of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels with a BaFe12O19 nanoparticle loading of 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5 wt% is 87.1, 65.1, and 23.4 kPa, respectively, Fig. 4B. The compression strength of
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels is lower than that of MBA/PAA hydrogel, but the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels are more flexible than the MBA/PAA hydrogel since the recovery ratio of
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels is almost 100% after 10 cycles with 80% of compression, exhibiting an excellent elasticity. The MBA/PAA hydrogel is around 88.5% under the same
condition. For strain sensing application, the recovery ratio of an elastomer is more important for achieving a stable electrical signal output.39 This is consistent with SEM results as shown
in Fig. 2. More porous structures in BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels (Fig. 2B and C) make the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels more elastic than MBA/PAA hydrogel (Fig. 2A) as aformentioned, which are beneficial for the durability of high compression. Therefore, the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels can be potentially used as strain sensors. Meanwhile, the compression strength of
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels is decreased with increasing the BaFe12O19 nanoparticle loading. This phenomenon is also noticed in the polyacrylamide (PAM)/carbon nanodot (C-dot) NC hydrogels,22 arising from the fact that the increased BaFe12O19 nanoparticle loadings may damage the uniformity of the cross-linked network of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels to some extent.

sections.heading: 3.4. Strain sensing properties of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels
sections.text:
Based on the compression measurements mentioned in Fig. 4, the porous
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel with a BaFe12O19 nanoparticle loading of 0.3 wt% is selected to study the strain sensing property of nanohybrid hydrogel since it gathers both the strength and
flexibility together, which favors stable electrical signal output upon compression. In
comparison, the MBA/PAA hydrogel is also measured for the same strain sensing test. The
strain sensing responsivity is defined as R/R0 = (R-R0)/R0, where R is the resistance after
applying compression stress and R0 is the initial resistance of hydrogels. The responsivity as a

function of strain up to 40% at a compression rate of 5 mm min-1 under the cyclic
compression with 10 cycles for MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels is plotted in Fig. 5A and B, and the corresponding compression stress-strain curves with a progressive
strain amplitudes (shown in inset) are depicted in Fig. 5C and D, accordingly. From the
electrical response during the compression cycles, Fig. 5A and B, it’s observed that the
electrical conductivity for both MBA/PAA hydrogel and BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel increases with increasing the strain (termed as negative piezoresistive behaviour), which is a common
phenomenon in the piezoresistive material and results from the formed more conductive networks during the compression process.40 After gradually releasing the stress, the resistance
returns to a high value. This may be related to the elasticity of both MBA/PAA hydrogel and
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel, in which the interconnected networks are broken again. However, the electrical signal (R/R0) for the MBA/PAA hydrogel continues to attenuate with elapsed
time, Fig. 5A, confirming the non-stable electrical signal output and harmful for the strain
sensing. By contrast, the R/R0 exhibits a relatively stable electrical signal output, Fig. 5B,
demonstrating that our BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel is more suitable to serve as a strain sensor than MBA/PAA hydrogel. This might be related to the porous structure of the
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel.
Besides, in order to investigate the sensitivity, stability and reversibility for 0.3 wt%
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel, the strain sensing behaviours were evaluated for 50 cycles with a compression strain of 40% at a strain rate of 5 mm min-1. The corresponding responsivity
variations during cycles of 1-10 and 41-50 are respectively listed in Fig. S4&6B. The strain
sensing behaviour for 0.3 wt% BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel exhibits similar profile in all the cycles under the stepwise compression. Yet, at the beginning 10 cycles, the R/R0 is not that
stable arising from the viscoelasticity of polymer. With increasing the cyclic compression, the
construction of perfect and stable conductive networks of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels endows

the hydrogel with a stable electrical signal output.41 The steady electrical output also indicates
a good recoverability and reproducibility of BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogels as strain sensors.
Furthermore, for the MBA/PAA hydrogel, the compression stress-strain curves during
the cyclic compression process are clearly separated, Fig. 5C. The obviously observed both
mechanical hysteresis loops (associated with the dissipated energy) and shoulder peaks during
the mechanical compression deformation are not suitable for a strain sensor, which are also found in the PAAm hydrogels.16 In addition, the stress-strain curves with negligible hysteresis
loops are observed in BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel, Fig. 5D, which almost coincide for all the load-unloading compression cycles. A bigger hysteresis loop means a larger energy dissipated during the cyclic compression experiments41 and the hydrogel possesses a lower elasticity with a poorer repeatability.42 This evidences that the BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel has a better recoverability and elasticity than the MBA/PAA hydrogel, which affirms that the
BaFe12O19/PAA hydrogel is more suitable for the strain sensing material than chemically covalently bonded MBA/PAA hydrogel. This result is consistent with the measured output
electrical signal.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, this work for the first time demonstrates smart flexible piezoresistive
strain sensing hybrid hydrogels based on the BaFe12O19 nanoparticles cross-linked PAA hydrogel without introducing any chemcial ingredient such as chemically covalent and ionic
cross-linkers. A more stable pieozeresistive strain sensing signal is accomplished in the
BaFe12O19/PAA hybrid hydrogel during the cyclic compression measurements compared with the MBA/PAA hydrogel. This BaFe12O19/PAA hybrid hydrogel exhibits excellent recoverability and elasticity arising from its more porous structure as verified by SEM images.
The negligible hysteresis loops in the BaFe12O19/PAA hybrid hydrogels further affirm the reproducibility and flexibility of this hybrid hydrogel. It is believed that the as-prepared

BaFe12O19/PAA hybrid hydrogel piezoresistive strain sensors could fulfill a wide requirements in the stretchable, wearable, flexible and human friendly soft electronic devices.
